PRJNA1399168.title: Metagenomic sequencing of environmental samples from foraging grounds and habitats of urban bats
PRJNA1399168.description: Vespertilio sinensis can mediate the spread of ARGs and VFGs in their foraging and habitat areas through trophic transfer and defecation behavior. We collected water, soil, insects from the foraging area, as well as bat feces, soil, and air samples near the roost, and performed metagenomic sequencing to characterize the microbiome, resistome, and virulome.

PRJNA1415085.title: Metagenomic Profiling of Antimicrobial Resistance in Wastewater from Metropolitan Cities of India
PRJNA1415085.description: Wastewater-based surveillance has emerged as a powerful tool for monitoring microbial diversity, antimicrobial resistance genes (ARGs) and mobile genetic elements (MGEs). In this study, wastewater samples collected from March 2022 to March 2024 from 19 locations in four metropolitan cities of India were profiled using shotgun metagenomics. Taxonomic abundance and beta diversity analyses revealed significant differences in microbial community compositions, with city-specific clustering; suggesting distinct local environmental influences. However, such distinct clusters were not evident with the ARGs. A high proportion of potentially novel metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) (53-70%) were identified on reconstructing the microbial genomes from the metagenomic data. ARGs conferring resistance to antibiotics such as tetracyclines and beta-lactams showed higher association with MGEs in contrast to macrolide resistance genes. Microbial co-occurrence network analysis revealed a city-specific structure and higher contribution of ARGs from specific communities of microbes. These findings underscore the complex interplay between microbial diversity, ARG dissemination, and MGEs in wastewater environments, emphasizing the need for continued surveillance, for designing appropriate mitigation strategies towards curbing the spread of antimicrobial resistance.
PRJNA1415085.center_name: CSIR-Center for Cellular and Molecular Biology

PRJNA1403178.title: Partial Nitrification and Thiocyanate-Driven Denitrification of industrial wastewater
PRJNA1403178.description: this study sought to elucidate how micro-oxic condition, when deliberately induced under controlled loading conditions, drives microbial community self-regulation and nitrogen and sulfur (N and S) synergistic metabolism in a single-stage bioreactor treating acrylic fiber wastewater. To achieve this, we established a stepwise SCN loading regime under constant aeration, enabling a progressive transition from oxic to micro-oxic conditions.

PRJNA1415247.title: Metaviromics for environmentally isolated phage samples
PRJNA1415247.description: We collected viromes from traditional and high-throughput phage isolation phage enrichments using E. coli MG1655 as a host.

PRJNA1414543.title: Urban wastewater Metagenome
PRJNA1414543.description: This project comprises shotgun metagenomic sequencing of 13 municipal wastewater samples collected from the influent of an urban wastewater treatment plant in Guelph, Ontario, Canada. Samples were collected between October 2023 and July 2024 and processed using the Illumina Viral Surveillance Panel 2 hybrid capture enrichment protocol to enhance detection of viral nucleic acids. Libraries were sequenced on an Illumina NextSeq 1000 platform (2 x 150 bp), and resulting reads were analyzed using the DRAGEN microbial enrichment plus pipeline for taxonomic profiling.

PRJNA1400247.title: Metagenome-assembled genomes from alkali-rich boron tailing ponds
PRJNA1400247.description: Boron mine tailing ponds are alkaline and boron-rich environments that harbor diverse bacterial communities adapted to extreme conditions. Metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) were reconstructed from shotgun metagenomic data to characterize the microbial diversity at the genomic level.

PRJNA1411669.title: Lakes and lagoons used for drinking water supply and fisheries as sources of potentially pathogenic bacteria and antimicrobial resistance
PRJNA1411669.description: Drinking water supplies and water basins used for fisheries represent two essential water sources for the sustenance of human activities. Despite the growing accessibility of metagenomic approaches, their routine use for the monitoring of water quality is still limited. In this study, surface water samples were collected in two different sites: the artificial lake Bidighinzu (drinking water supply) and the coastal lagoon Cabras (fisheries), both located in the Mediterranean area. Samples were analyzed by 16S rRNA gene amplicon and shotgun sequencings and their bacterial communities, pathobiomes, and antimicrobial resistomes were characterized. An experiment was also conducted to evaluate how the bacterial community, pathobiome, and antimicrobial resistome of these two water sources respond to a simulated heat wave, which is increasingly frequent in the era of climate change.

PRJEB106897.title: microbiome in acne lesional versus healthy skin
PRJEB106897.description: The biological state of clinically non-lesional skin in acne remains incompletely characterized, despite its potential relevance to disease progression and early intervention. Using longitudinal multi-omics profiling, including 16S rRNA gene sequencing (V1–V3 and V4), shotgun metagenomics, and UPLC-MS/MS metabolomics, of facial skin from 10 individuals with acne (lesional and non-lesional sites) and 10 healthy controls across multiple time points, we identified microbial and metabolic differences across healthy, non-lesional, and lesional skin. Compositional tensor factorization showed that non-lesional acne skin occupied an intermediate position between healthy and lesional skin in both microbiome and metabolome profiles. Acne-associated skin displayed reduced microbial diversity with strain-level and temporal changes correlating with lesion severity. Machine learning classification distinguished healthy from acne lesional samples (AUC=0.67) and healthy from acne non-lesional samples (AUC=0.70). Metabolomics revealed widespread lipid alterations, including elevated N-oleoylethanolamine (a PPAR-α agonist related to sebum production) consistently present in both non-lesional and lesional acne skin. Amino acid perturbations, particularly of (iso)leucine, tryptophan, and phenylalanine, were pronounced even in non-lesional sites. Integrative microbe–metabolite association analyses revealed distinct co-occurrence patterns in acne, while healthy skin showed enrichment of protective metabolites including urocanic acid. These findings indicate that clinically normal-appearing skin in individuals with acne exhibits measurable microbial and metabolic differences compared to healthy skin, providing a foundation for future studies evaluating candidate biomarkers and microbiome-informed intervention strategies.
PRJEB106897.center_name: University of California San Diego Microbiome Initiative

PRJNA1336326.title: Developing and Benchmarking One Health Genomic Surveillance  Tools for Influenza A Virus in Wastewater
PRJNA1336326.description: We benchmarked four targeted enrichment methods suited for sequencing-based surveillance of Influenza A Virus in wastewater: 1) a custom probe-capture enrichment panel, 2) a custom tiled-amplicon panel for the HA segment, 3) the Twist Comprehensive Viral Research probe-capture panel, 4) the universal amplicon method developed by Zhou et al 2009. We tested these 4 methods a) on direct mixtures of wastewater RNA and RNA from 4 strains of Influenza A virus, and b) on incubated mixtures of Influenza A Viruses spiked into wastewater and concentrated by either Promega Wizard Enviro TNA kit or Innovaprep CP Select + Qiagen AllPrep PowerViral extraction kit.

PRJNA1405282.title: Metagenomic analysis of microbial metabolism in a micro-aerobic hydrolytic acidification reactor treating printing and dyeing wastewater
PRJNA1405282.description: The limited understanding of microbial metabolic regulation mechanisms in microaerophilic hydrolysis-acidification reactors for textile wastewater restricts their widespread application. This project aims to investigate functional genes and metabolic potential within such reactors. Using metagenomic sequencing technology, we elucidate the regulatory effects of dissolved oxygen gradients on functional genes related to carbon metabolism, volatile fatty acid (VFA) synthesis, and azo dye degradation. The resulting metagenome dataset reveals metabolic regulatory mechanisms of microorganisms under microaerophilic conditions, providing a theoretical basis for optimizing hydrolysis-acidification systems in textile wastewater treatment.

PRJNA1405098.title: Loigolactobacillus coryniformis isolated from healthy dairy cows
PRJNA1405098.description: The microorganisms were isolated from healthy dairy cows in Shihezi City, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region.

PRJNA1403038.title: Shotgun metagenomics reveal that anticancer drugs drive variations in the functional microbiome and resistome of a sequential-flow aerobic granular sludge system
PRJNA1403038.description: In this study, we investigated the combined effects of three widely detected cytotoxic pharmaceuticals (cyclophosphamide (CP), methotrexate (MTX), and tamoxifen (TMX)) on the diversity and community composition, functional microbiome, and resistome of an aerobic granular sludge (AGS) system operated in sequential batch reactor (SBR) mode. A 90-day experiment was conducted and a treatment without drugs was used as a control.

PRJNA1397491.title: Acidic mine wastewater Metagenome
PRJNA1397491.description: provide new insights for AMD management under future climate change.

PRJNA1402132.title: Surveillance of antimicrobial resistance in the healthcare setting using a rapid metagenomics-based approach
PRJNA1402132.description: This study focused on the development of a rapid metagenomics approach for the surveillance of antimicrobial resistant microorganisms in healthcare environments. This approach integrates an extraction protocol optimised for low-biomass samples with long-read metagenomics sequencing to capture the total genetic diversity of microbial communities samples from the air and surfaces of clinical and non-clinical locations.

PRJNA1403741.title: Wastewater metagenome
PRJNA1403741.description: The samples were collected from the stages of six printing and dyeing wastewater treatment plants, specifically from the influent, anaerobic, aerobic, and effluent sections.

PRJNA1403069.title: Electrically enhanced microalgae-bacteria systems for wastewater treatment under low-temperature conditions
PRJNA1403069.description: Low temperatures severely limit biological activity and pollutant removal in municipal wastewater treatment systems. This study comparatively evaluated micro electric fields (MEF) and pulsed electric fields (PEF) for enhancing a microalgae-bacteria system (MBS) treating real municipal wastewater at 5 - 15 degrees Celsius. Both electric field modes significantly improved biomass accumulation, photosynthetic pigment synthesis, Extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) production, and nutrient and chemical oxygen demand (COD) removal compared with non-electrified controls. PEF provided stronger short-term stimulation of biomass growth and pollutant removal, particularly at 10 - 15 degrees Celsius, whereas MEF showed more stable enhancement at 5 degrees Celsius. Phosphorus removal exhibited a pronounced electrochemical-biological synergy, electrocoagulation created favorable flocculation conditions, while biological assimilation and EPS-mediated aggregation contributed over 60% of total TP removal across all temperatures. Energy analysis further showed that PEF reduced volumetric energy consumption by 20 - 50% relative to MEF at equivalent voltages. Overall, electro-assisted microalgal-bacterial treatment offers an energy-efficient strategy for wastewater management under low temperature conditions.

PRJNA1398875.title: Functional redundancy and stability support the resilience of the Evernia prunastri holobiont under urbanization
PRJNA1398875.description: An integrative multi-omics study testing whether urbanization alters microbiome composition and functional potential in the Evernia prunastri holobiont.

PRJNA1338502.title: Molecular Approaches for Quantifying and Characterizing the Microbiome of Low-Biomass Spacecraft Environments
PRJNA1338502.description: Microbial contamination poses a critical risk to the scientific integrity of astrobiology missions, particularly those aimed at detecting life or returning samples from potentially habitable extraterrestrial environments. To comply with NASA Planetary Protection (PP) standards, spacecraft surfaces are currently evaluated using the NASA Standard Assay (NSA) - a cultivation-based method that detects only heat-shock-resistant, aerobic, heterotrophic, spore-forming bacteria. The overarching goal of this study is to establish and validate a next-generation molecular framework for quantifying (qPCR) and characterizing microbial burden (shotgun metagenome sequencing) on spacecraft-associated environmental surfaces. We employ an integrated approach combining optimized sample collection, metagenomic sequencing, and dPCR-based enumeration to enable high-resolution, contamination-resilient microbial surveillance in support of NASA's evolving PP needs. This study addresses a critical knowledge and capability gap by directly comparing molecular tools for determining cleanliness of spacecraft associated surfaces and evaluating their sensitivity, specificity, and reproducibility across a range of surface types and bioburden levels.

PRJEB105368.title: Anxiety associated with dietary intake and gut microbiome features in a cross-sectional cohort of sub-clinically anxious young women.
PRJEB105368.description: Emerging evidence highlights the gut-brain axis as a key pathway linking diet and anxiety, but the specific dietary and gut microbiome drivers remain unclear. In this study, we investigated associations between dietary intake, gut microbiome composition, and anxiety in a subclinical cohort of 46 females (18–24 years) from the United Kingdom.  Long-term diet quality was assessed using the Healthy Eating Index (HEI-2020) derived from a food frequency questionnaire, stratifying participants into lower and higher diet quality clusters. Short-term dietary intake was assessed via 24-hour recalls. Shotgun metagenomics of stool samples was used to assees differences in α and β diversity indices, species abundances, and bacterial pathways putatively metabolizing gut-brain-axis relevant molecules. Anxiety was measured using the State–Trait Anxiety Inventory (state subscale – STAI-s).  Regression models identified diet quality (HEI cluster) as the primary dietary feature of anxiety variation. The presence of Ruminococcus B gnavus and Flavonifractor plautii, and the abundances of several species were positively associated with STAI-s, with Bilophila wadsworthia explaining 40% of its variance. The presence of Feacalibacterium prausnitzii and greater abundances of butyrate, propionate, and GABA synthesis pathways were inversely associated with anxiety. Non-linear models revealed a U-shaped relationship between inositol synthesis and STAI-s. Finally, we found that habitual diet quality may modulate anxiety-related responses to short-term dietary variation.  These findings reveal widespread links between long-term diet quality, microbiota composition and function, and anxiety symptoms. These results point towards several promising targets for prebiotic, probiotic, postbiotic, and dietary interventions targets aimed at reducing anxiety.

PRJNA1393412.title: Exogenous CO2 Modulates Methane Production in Anaerobic Digestion: Insights into Substrate-Dependent Metabolic Regulation
PRJNA1393412.description: Exogenous CO2 injection has shown inconsistent effects on anaerobic digestion performance due to variations in substrate properties and operational parameters. This study investigated the effects of CO2 injection on microbial community composition, key metabolic pathways, and methane yield. CO2 influenced bacterial populations, promoting the enrichment of hydrolytic acidogenic microbes that accelerate the breakdown of complex organics and generate precursors for methanogenesis, while methanogenic archaea remained stable, maintaining both acetoclastic and hydrogenotrophic pathways. Functional gene analysis showed enhanced abundances in the Acetyl CoA and Wood Ljungdahl pathways, indicating improved carbon flux toward methane precursors, whereas excessive CO2 could potentially limit Coenzyme M availability by overproducing Acetyl-CoA, highlighting the need for controlled dosing. Operational optimization identified a food waste-to-sludge ratio of 3:1 and an organic load of 5 g VS L-1 d-1 as optimal, yielding 0.159 L CH4/g VS, outperforming other tested ratios. These results demonstrate that CO2 injection can effectively improve substrate conversion efficiency and methane production while maintaining microbial stability. The findings provide practical guidance for high-load anaerobic digestion management and illustrate the potential of CO2 modulation to enhance system performance.
PRJNA1393412.center_name: University of Shanghai for Science and Technology

PRJEB101092.title: A spatiotemporal analysis of the microbial community on the surface of public places in urban areas of Xi'an
PRJEB101092.description: Representative China public locations within the selected Xi'an public places were sampled across four seasons, from April 2023 to April 2024. The sampling sites were included in the study: the Xi'an Bell Tower Subway Station, the Zhuque Agricultural and Sideline Products Logistics Center, the Second Affiliated Hospital of Xi'an Jiaotong University, the Teaching Building of Xi'an University of Posts and Telecommunications, the Xi'an Light Industry Wholesale Market, and Xi'an Huimin Square tourist attractions.
PRJEB101092.center_name: College of Life Science, Shaanxi Normal University

PRJNA1392016.title: self-driven bio-electrochemical system for efficient nitrogen and phosphorus removal of wastewater
PRJNA1392016.description: It was first discovered that connecting iron-carbon located in different functional areas of the sewage treatment process with wire could enable the flow of electrons across regions. Batch experiments demonstrated that an iron-carbon self-driven bio-electrochemical system (SD-BES) significantly enhances the denitrification rate of microbial community. Leveraging this finding, we designed a SD-BES trickling filter in which iron-carbon electrodes are spatially separated into an anoxic zone and a micro-oxic zone and connected by a single wire to enable cross-zone electron flow for treating real municipal sewage.

PRJNA1389881.title: A novel approach for achieving ultra-high enrichment of anaerobic ammonium oxidizing bacteria and nitrogen removal rate in municipal wastewater treatment: A pure biofilm process without suspended sludge
PRJNA1389881.description: Metagenomic sequencing revealed the carbon and nitrogen metabolic pathways of functional bacteria in the pure biofilm system, showing that AnAOBs metabolic diversity and ecological niche adaptation within the biofilm structure drove their self-enrichment.

PRJEB83552.title: SEPSIS Lactobacillus plantarum ATCC 202195 Microbiome Study
PRJEB83552.description: Recent randomized controlled trials (RCTs) have demonstrated the beneficial effects of probiotics and/or prebiotics, compared to placebo, for preventing infections in preterm and/or LBW infant. Some of the most compelling evidence comes from a recent randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled trial conducted by Panigrahi and colleagues, where newborns (≥ 35 weeks ‘gestation and ≥ 2,000 grams) residing in rural India were randomized to receive Lactobacillus plantarum (L. plantarum) ATCC 202195 plus fructooligosaccharide (FOS), or placebo, once daily for seven consecutive days, starting on day two to four of life. Relative to the placebo group, infants in the synbiotic group had a 40% lower risk of the combined primary outcome of sepsis and all-cause mortality, and a 78% lower risk of culture-confirmed sepsis. As a result of the promising safety profile and strong mechanistic rationale regarding its plausible probiotic effects, L. plantarum has garnered interest as a potential intervention for preventing sepsis and pSBI in infants. Although the Panigrahi et al. study provides strong evidence for the proposed beneficial effects,the effects of L. plantarum administration on the infant microbiome has not been fully described. Most of what we know about the microbiome comes from high-income settings. This is because, low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) are currently underrepresented in global microbiome study. In addition, recent work highlights the influence of geography on the composition and stability of the gut microbiota. This study will examine the effects of neonatal oral administration of Lactobacillus plantarum (L. plantarum) ATCC 202195 (109 CFU/day) with fructooligosaccharide (FOS), versus placebo, on the community structure, diversity and metabolite production of the microbiota of infants in Dhaka, Bangladesh
PRJEB83552.center_name: University of California San Diego Microbiome Initiative

PRJEB102709.title: Viral metagenomics of pig feces and sewage
PRJEB102709.description: Samples 1–3 consist of viral-enriched metagenomic DNA extracted from pig feces, while samples 4–5 originate from sewage. Metagenomic DNA was sequenced by Eurofins Genomics using the INVIEW METAGENOME service. Sequencing included standard genomic library preparation followed by paired-end Illumina sequencing (2 × 150 bp), generating a minimum of 10 million read pairs per sample.       Raw sequencing reads were processed with the ViPER pipeline (Virome Paired-End Reads) to generate viral contigs (De Coninck et al., 2024). This pipeline applies Trimmomatic (Bolger et al., 2014) to trim low-quality bases and adapters from raw reads, followed by assembling the paired-end reads of 1 %, 10 % and 100 % subsets into contigs using metaSPAdes (Nurk et al., 2017). These contigs were clustered using a combination of BLAST+ (Camacho et al., 2009), and anicalc.py and aniclust.py scripts from the CheckV packages (Nayfach et al., 2021). Contigs larger than 500 bp were retained.

PRJNA1367777.title: Overwintering waterbirds are important reservoirs for the spread of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs): Shared patterns at the waterbird-environment interface and the risk of horizontal transfer
PRJNA1367777.description: The global spread of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) has posed a severe challenge to public health. Long-distance migratory waterbirds are considered important biological vectors for the cross-regional transmission of ARGs. However, the sharing patterns and potential transfer risks of ARGs between migratory waterbirds and their habitats during the overwintering period are still unclear, which limits the systematic understanding of the role of migratory waterbirds in the transmission of ARGs. This study takes a typical overwintering wetland in Southwest China along the East Asian Australasian Flyway as the research object and systematically analyzes the sharing characteristics and transfer risks of ARGs in the intestines of overwintering waterbirds and their aquatic and terrestrial habitats based on metagenomics methods.

PRJEB83776.title: Air sampling accurately captures circulating zoonotic viral diversity emerging from poultry live-animal markets
PRJEB83776.description: Environmental surveillance has emerged as a pivotal strategy for early detection of pathogens that pose threats to humans but has not been utilized for zoonotic agents. In Asia, live-bird markets (LBMs) are key human-animal interfaces for zoonotic virus transmission. Traditional sampling strategies are time-consuming, expensive, threaten animal welfare and have significant occupational biosafety risks. In this study, we assessed the performance of metagenomics on environmental samples (ES)  compared to traditional poultry swabs for detecting avian viral pathogens in LBMs in Cambodia. ES, including air, cage swabs, and carcass wash water, were collected alongside throat and cloacal swabs from domestic chickens and ducks across twelve sampling visits in two LBMs over a 15-month period. Viral nucleic acids were extracted and sequenced using a capture probe-based metagenomics approach. Our results show that metagenomics on ES outperformed traditional poultry samples in detecting the highly pathogenic Influenza A/H5N1, including circulating clades 2.3.4.4b and 2.3.2.1c, which were found in the environment but missed by poultry swabs on multiple occasions. Environmental metagenomics was also highly sensitive in the detection of over 40 other viruses from key pathogen families such as Astroviridae, Coronaviridae, Picornaviridae, and Retroviridae. Viral contigs from ES showed high similarity to those from poultry swabs further highlighting the accuracy of this approach. Our findings highlight metagenomics on ES can precisely and effectively replicate metagenomic results from traditional surveillance samples, offering broader coverage and enhanced detection of avian pathogens. This robust approach could be pivotal for mitigating zoonotic spillover, controlling pathogen transmission at LBMs, and enhancing pandemic preparedness strategies.

PRJNA1297605.title: oxygenic photogranule metagenome Genome sequencing
PRJNA1297605.description: Oxygenic photogranules (OPGs) are biological aggregates primarily composed of cyanobacteria, eukaryotic algae, and heterotrophic bacteria interacting syntrophically. Recognized for their potential in wastewater treatment, OPGs cultivated in sequencing batch reactors are subjected to frequent fluctuations in light and carbon availability, potentially impacting their metabolic activity, syntrophic relationships and depuration abilities. However, the metabolic responses of OPGs to such environmental changes and their consequences on community function and interactions, remain poorly understood. Here the purpose of the project was to identify how OPG community structure and functions evolve when subjected to changes in carbon (acetate) and light and whether these environmental changes exert lasting effects.

PRJNA1375486.title: Engineered carbon-depleted zone in Anaerobic/Aerobic/Anoxic process as a key in-situ anammox incubation hub for mainstream municipal wastewater treatment
PRJNA1375486.description: Competitive nitrite consumption by heterotrophic organisms and the carbon sensitivity of anammox bacteria limit mainstream anammox performance. This study demonstrates that deliberately established carbon-depleted zones within anaerobic/aerobic/anoxic (AOA) processes served as in-situ anammox incubation hubs by regulating endogenous and exogenous carbon metabolism, achieving 92.3% nitrogen removal with 59.4% via anammox and effluent total inorganic nitrogen of 5.1 mg/L at C/N 3.2.

PRJNA1373497.title: Exploration of viral diversity in Aedes mosquitoes employing different shotgun metagenomic data analysis pipeline.
PRJNA1373497.description: In this study, shotgun metagenomic methodology using ION Torrent platform was optimized for exploration of viral diversity. A total of 1913 Aedes larvae were collected from Central India during post monsoon season in 2024. Aedes larvae reared to adult and processed through ION Torrent sequencing. Computational analysis was performed using three different pipelines: CHAN ZUCKERBERG ID (czid.org), Genome Detective Platform and Galaxy tool. A mock database of 11 known viruses was created to validate all three pipelines. In terms of accuracy, genome detective and CZID performed exceptionally well in detection and hence can be used in future studies. We found presence of viruses viz Alphamesonivirus cavallynese and Phasivirus phasinese dominating in all samples. Dengue virus detected in one sample by CZID, where as Wenhzou sobemo-like virus, Hubei mosquito virus 2, Cell fusing agent virus, found most commonly among samples. Other viruses found like Gylbovirus aagae (Aedes anphevirus), Aedes totivirus, Verdadero virus, Chaq-like virus etc. The variation in the result in different pipeline is due incorporation of different databases, algorithms, metrics and parameters.

PRJEB103765.description: Metagenomes were generated from faecal samples collected from wild roosters and bat rescue centers in Yorkshire, UK

PRJEB87631.title: Innovative wastewater treatment intensification for stringent nitrogen and N2O control
PRJEB87631.description: This study develops innovative wastewater treatment technologies to enhance nitrogen removal efficiency and significantly reduce nitrous oxide (N₂O) emissions—a potent greenhouse gas. Using rapid redox fluctuations and integrated metagenomics and metabolomics modeling, our approach enables wastewater systems to meet stringent nitrogen discharge regulations, accurately measure emissions, and substantially reduce their carbon footprint.

PRJNA1356485.title: Anaerobic digestion of propionate in lab-scale reactors: community structure and function
PRJNA1356485.description: This project investigates microbial communities and functions in lab-scale anaerobic digestion reactors fed with propionate as the primary substrate under mesophilic conditions. We profile community dynamics, operating parameters, and performance to understand propionate degradation and methanogenesis in engineered anaerobic systems.

PRJNA1339027.title: Manganese cycle-mediated synchronous bacteria-algae/anammox coupled denitrification system under low-temperature conditions
PRJNA1339027.description: The study constructed a manganese redox cycle-mediated synchronous bacteria-algae/anaerobic ammonium oxidation coupled denitrification system (SAAD) and investigated the feasibility of enhancing the low-temperature resistance of the anammox-coupled denitrification process by adding Mn@BC.The results demonstrated that under low-temperature conditions, the average nitrogen removal efficiency increased to 82% with Mn@BC addition, whereas it remained at 73% with BC alone. Additionally, Mn@BC supplementation enhanced extracellular polymeric substance (EPS) secretion and enriched the microbial community structure.Furthermore, the rapidly growing microalgae absorbed substantial amounts of nitrogen and phosphorus through photosynthesis, achieving synchronous N&P removal, with the phosphorus removal efficiency maintained at 51%. TOC analysis confirmed that photosynthesis generated dissolved organic carbon (DOC), thereby reducing the system's reliance on external organic carbon sources.Metagenomic sequencing was employed to investigate the functional microorganisms and potential metabolic pathways. By integrating reactor performance, sludge characteristics, and microbial community structure, the microbial interactions were elucidated, thereby proposing a potential mechanism of the Mn@BC-enhanced SAAD system under low-temperature conditions.

PRJEB104033.title: Effect of the hydrothermal carbonization temperature on the conversion of process water produced from food waste in a mesophilic UASB digester
PRJEB104033.description: The conversion of process water (PW) produced during the hydrothermal carbonization (HTC) of organic waste by anaerobic digestion (AD) offers the opportunity to reduce the organic load of this aqueous phase and increase the overall energy yield of the process. The AD of PW produced at two different temperatures (180°C and 240°C) in up-flow anaerobic sludge blanket digesters was carried out to determine the effect of HTC temperature on AD performance and the associated microbial communities.
PRJEB104033.center_name: National Research Council Canada, Clean Energy Innovation Research Centre

PRJNA1359455.title: In-situ enriching anammox bacteria in mainstream suspended sludge system: Feasibility, Performance, and Mechanism analysis
PRJNA1359455.description: The viability of in-situ enriching anammox bacteria in a suspended sludge system was investigated in order to facilitate applying mainstream anammox.

PRJDB30870.description: Sludge genome before and after adding Fe3O4 to the cathode of bioelectrochemical system

PRJNA1204190.title: The global WWTPs activated sludge microbe catalog GWASMC
PRJNA1204190.description: This study conducted a large-scale excavation of microbes by reconstructing 24,534 metagenome-assembled genomes from 828 WWTP metagenomes and developed a comprehensive global WWTP activate sludge microbe catalog (GWSAMC) and gene catalog (GWASGC).

PRJNA1365488.title: Whole genome sequencing of Klebsiella pneumoniae strain Klep3588 isolated from hospital wastewater in Iraq
PRJNA1365488.description: This project involves whole-genome sequencing of Klebsiella pneumoniae strain Klep3588, isolated from hospital wastewater in Babylon, Iraq. The isolate was obtained during experiments investigating the microbial biodegradation of the pharmaceutical compound ibuprofen. The generated genomic data will support the identification of genes related to stress tolerance, xenobiotic degradation, and environmental adaptation.

PRJNA1359613.title: Capacitive Bimetallic Redox Cycles and Ligand-to-metal Charge Transfer to Boost Denitrification with NiII/FeII-Gallic Acid Phenolic Networks
PRJNA1359613.description: Biological denitrification is limited by slow nitrate (NO3-) reduction due to low electron transfer efficiency, unsatisfactory community functional efficiency and insufficient metabolic activity of microbial communities. To overcome these challenges, Ni2+ and Fe2+ were incorporated with gallic acid (GA) to form bimetallic polyphenol networks (NiFeGA BPNs) with low-cost and high-biocompatibility. NiFeGA BPNs exhibited capacitive Ni(II)/Fe(II) redox cycles and excellent ligand-to-metal charge transfer capabilities to enable complete degradation of 200 mg/L NO3- within 8 h. All these improvements could be ascribed to that NiFeGA BPNs significantly improved electron transfer efficiency and stimulated microbial metabolic activity, which were proved by extracellular polymeric substances electrochemical analysis and electron transport chain inhibitors experiments. More importantly, metagenomic sequencing analysis confirmed that NiFeGA BPNs improved community structure by directionally enriching Pseudomonas. Consequently, NiFeGA BPNs significantly improving denitrification, which provides both theoretical guidance and technical frameworks for the continuous and efficient treatment of nitrate in wastewater.

PRJNA1365682.title: Microbial communities and metabolic processes in a pilot-scale ultra-high biophase HPB system for high-ammonia wastewater treatment
PRJNA1365682.description: In this study, derived from high-concentration powder carrier bio-fluidized bed (HPB) technology, a novel ultra-high biophase HPB (UBH) technology was proposed to address the needs of high-ammonia wastewater treatment. The microbial communities and metabolism in UBH system were explored by metagenomic analysis.

PRJNA1344771.title: Microbial sequencing
PRJNA1344771.center_name: Xi 'an University of Architecture and Technology

PRJEB103008.title: Iron regulation of sulfur-mediated autotrophic denitrification: denitrification efficiency, microbial dynamics, and metabolic pathways
PRJEB103008.description: The application of iron sulfide-mediated, autotrophic denitrification is promising for nitrate reduction in carbon (organics)-deficient wastewater and polluted groundwater. Previous research shows that different iron sulfide lead to distinct functional microbial communities, obscuring how iron modulates their composition and activity. In this study, different iron levels were applied to isolate the effects of S and Fe and investigated iron-modulated denitrification efficiency, microbial succession, and key pathways.

PRJEB97976.title: Infant gut microbiome maturation during weaning
PRJEB97976.description: The infant gut microbiome develops dynamically during the first year of life, with the introduction of solid foods and the gradual cessation of breastfeeding marking key milestones. This study investigated how the weaning drives the maturation of the infant gut microbiome.

PRJEB102491.title: Shotgun sequencing of 91 infants from the ALADDIN birth cohort
PRJEB102491.description: ALADDIN is a prospective birth cohort study that focuses on the impact of lifestyle and environmental factors during pregnancy and childhood on the development of allergic disease. To study the role of gut microbiota in the developement of allergic disease, faecal samples from infants were shot-gun sequenced. This study accession includes 91 additional infants to the 56 infants included in ALADDIN birth cohort.

PRJEB102229.title: Surface Vacancies in Iron Sulfides Drive Denitrification Mechanisms
PRJEB102229.description: Global nitrogen cycling is tightly governed by iron and sulfur biogeochemical processes in anoxic environments, while the mechanism of surface vacancy structures of iron sulfides on nitrate transformation remains unclear. This research demonstrated that pyrrhotite with iron vacancies and lower Fe–S bond energy (1.35 eV) facilitated efficient electron transfer and microbial utilization of reduced sulfur to achieve nitrate autotrophic denitrification to dinitrogen. Conversely, FeS2, possessing strong Fe–S bonding (1.63 eV), showed minimal reactivity due to restricted electron mobility. FeS, with intermediate bond energy (1.39 eV) and abundant sulfur vacancies, supported simultaneous abiotic nitrate–to–ammonium conversion and microbial denitrification. These mineral−specific mechanisms support nitrogen transformations in diverse anoxic systems, from wetland to marine sediments, ultimately determining the global nitrogen cycling. Furthermore, tuning iron sulfide phases and vacancy structures presents novel strategies for sustainable, wastewater treatment, steering nitrate removal toward nutrient recovery or benign gas production.

PRJNA1295920.title: US National Wastewater Surveillance System (NWSS) wastewater project: Kansas Health and Environment Laboratory
PRJNA1295920.description: Raw sequence data targeting SARS-CoV-2 in wastewater samples. These data were collected as part of the Kansas Health & Environment Laboratories for monitoring SARS-CoV-2 variants in wastewater.

PRJNA1092662.title: GenomeTrakr Project: Thakur Molecular Epidemiology Laboratory, NC State University
PRJNA1092662.description: Whole genome sequencing of cultured Klebsiella as part of the US Food and Drug Administration surveillance project for the rapid detection of outbreaks of foodborne illnesses.
PRJNA1092662.center_name: GenomeTrakr Project: Thakur Molecular Epidemiology Laboratory, NC State University

PRJNA293225.title: MULTI-DRUG RESISTANT ESCHERICHIA COLI IN HUMANS, POULTRY AND POULTRYENVIRONMENT IN THE FEDERAL CAPITAL TERRITORY, NIGERIA: POTENTIAL RISK FOR HUMAN HEALTH
PRJNA293225.description: The aim of this study is to determine the occurrence of antibiotic residues in poultry and the drug resistance patterns of E. coli isolates obtained from humans, poultry and the poultry environment in the Federal Capital Territory (FCT),Nigeria.This project is related to PRJNA293225 which is the project of Thakur Molecular Epidemiology Laboratory, NC State University (GenomeTrakr Project).

PRJNA1347544.title: Rapid start-up of simultaneous nitrogen removal and sludge reduction in a single reactor through fermented sludge bioaugmentation
PRJNA1347544.description: Integrating anammox with fermentation is expected to achieve efficient nitrogen removal and in-situ reduction of excess sludge, which can significantly reduce the cost of mainstream wastewater treatment. In this research, the feasibility of rapid start-up of simultaneous partial nitrification, anammox, denitrification and fermentation (SNADF) process by fermented sludge bioaugmentation was studied. In addition, excess sludge was regularly supplied to the system to explore the sludge treatment potential of the SNADF system. Within 81 days, the SNADF system achieved efficient nitrogen removal (88.17%), coupled with significant sludge reduction capability (Yobs: -0.394 kgMLSS/kgCOD). An in-situ test revealed the synergistic relationship between fermentation and partial denitrification/anammox (PD/A) in the absence of organics, indicating the start-up of SNADF system. Moreover, the continuous decrease in biomass concentration indicated the considerable potential of SNADF in treating the excess sludge. The anaerobic ammonia oxidizing bacteria (AnAOB) were obviously enriched (0.03%-0.25%), ensuring efficient nitrogen removal. The ammonia oxidizing bacteria in excess sludge facilitated AnAOB enrichment, while the excess sludge increased biomass concentration and promoted fermentation. The fermentation process mainly stopped at the acid-producing stage and promoted PD/A process. These results suggest that the SNADF system simultaneously promoted fermentation and nitrogen removal in a single reactor.

PRJNA1345882.title: Water sample metagenomics
PRJNA1345882.description: Metagenomic sequencing of water samples from natural and industrial reservoirs in Kisumu, Kenya, to investigate the distribution of pathogenic microorganisms, virulence factors, and antibiotic resistance genes in the Lake Victoria basin

PRJNA1346286.title: Environmental Bioinformatics in Carbon-Rich and Carbon-Poor Municipal Wastewater Treatment Systems
PRJNA1346286.description: Environmental samples were collected from an actual municipal wastewater treatment system. This system transitioned from a traditional carbon-rich denitrification environment to an intermittent carbon-poor denitrification environment. Biological information was derived from both distinct denitrification environments.

PRJNA1344785.title: Metagenomic Profiling of Microbial Ecology in Sugar Industry Wastewater
PRJNA1344785.description: This study explores the hidden microbial world in sugar industry wastewater through metagenomic sequencing. By capturing and analyzing the complete DNA of microbial communities, it reveals the diversity, ecological interactions, and functional potential of bacteria, archaea, and fungi in this industrial wastewater environment, offering insights for sustainable waste management and biotechnological applications.

PRJNA1344786.title: Metagenomic Decoding of Microbiomes in Food Wastewater
PRJNA1344786.description: This project investigates the microbial communities present in food industry wastewater using a metagenomic approach. By extracting and sequencing the total microbial DNA, it aims to uncover the diversity of bacteria, archaea, and fungi, as well as their potential functional roles. The findings will provide insights into microbial ecology, nutrient cycling, and opportunities for biotechnological applications such as wastewater treatment and resource recovery.

PRJNA1344783.title: Insights into Microbial Diversity of Rice Mill Wastewater through Metagenomic Analysis
PRJNA1344783.description: This study explores the microbial diversity present in rice mill wastewater using a metagenomic approach. By analyzing the total microbial DNA, we aim to identify and characterize the bacterial, archaeal, and fungal communities that thrive in this environment. The results will help understand the ecological composition, potential functional roles, and biotechnological applications of microorganisms in rice mill wastewater.

PRJNA1344777.title: Revealing the microbial diversity present in septic tank wastewater using a metagenomic approach
PRJNA1344777.description: This study explores the microbial diversity present in septic tank wastewater using a metagenomic approach. High-throughput sequencing was employed to identify and classify bacterial and archaeal communities without the need for culturing. The analysis revealed the dominance of key functional microbes involved in organic matter degradation and nutrient cycling. These findings provide valuable insights into the microbial ecology of septic systems and their potential role in wastewater treatment.

PRJNA1310670.title: Full-Scale AOA Process for Advanced Nitrogen Removal from Low-Strength Municipal Wastewater under Ultra-Low Air-Water Ratios
PRJNA1310670.description: Full-Scale AOA Process for Advanced Nitrogen Removal from Low-Strength Municipal Wastewater under Ultra-Low Air-Water Ratios

PRJEB98012.title: Creeping Fat
PRJEB98012.description: A study of bacterial translocation into mesenteric fat in Crohn's disease.
PRJEB98012.center_name: University of California San Diego Microbiome Initiative

PRJNA1336410.title: Hybrid Assembly
PRJNA1336410.description: Paired Illumina and Oxford nanopore sequencing set on a collection of wastewater samples and mock microbiomes for exploring efficacy of hybrid assembly technique for recovery of complete bacterial genomes for infectious disease surveillance.

PRJNA1335264.title: Exploring Antimicrobial Resistance Genes in an Urban Coati (Nasua nasua)
PRJNA1335264.description: The spread of antimicrobial resistance genes (ARGs) in wildlife represents a significant concern due to its potential impact on public health and ecosystem functioning. This study aimed to investigate the occurrence and diversity of ARGs in the fecal microbiota of coatis (Nasua nasua) inhabiting an urban ecological park in Belo Horizonte, Minas Gerais, Brazil. Fecal samples from individuals of different age and sex classes - including adult, subadult, and infant males and females - were analyzed for genes belonging to the tet, lnu, qnr, cmy, dfr, sul, erm, and ant families, which confer resistance to multiple antimicrobial classes. Results revealed that adult males harbored the highest diversity of ARGs, a pattern consistent with their social and dispersal behavior, which exposes them to a wider range of environmental microbial sources. These findings highlight the potential role of wildlife social structure and movement patterns in shaping the acquisition and dissemination of ARGs, emphasizing the importance of monitoring urban wildlife as part of strategies to understand and mitigate antimicrobial resistance.

PRJNA1174264.title: Inoculum microbial communities for bioreactor in University of Wisconsin-Madison, WI, USA - FK_LacMBR1_day21 metagenome
PRJNA1174264.description: Inoculum (biosafety level 2 culture from a wastewater treatment plant), day 21 of domestication

PRJNA1333281.title: Metagenomics of water microorganisms in Zhengzhou City Batch 3
PRJNA1333281.description: Metagenomics of water microorganisms in Zhengzhou City Batch 3

PRJNA1328447.title: Bacterial populations in Zimbabwe wastewater 2021
PRJNA1328447.description: Shotgun metagenomic sequences from Zimbabwe wastewater, 2021. Samples were collected to identify the bacterial community composition and associated resistome.

PRJEB97947.title: Assessment of seasonal airborne resistome dynamics in response to air pollution exposure in the Belgrade metropolitan area – winter
PRJEB97947.description: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) and air pollution have been identified as one of the most serious threats to human health worldwide. The scarce data demonstrating their interdependence indicates a need to obtain evidence from a broader global area, especially from regions exposed to high air pollution. Considering that Serbia is a country struggling with excessive antibiotics use and misuse, a high percentage of multidrug-resistant bacterial isolates, and poor air quality, the Serbian capital Belgrade has been recognized as an interesting research model for the effects of air pollution on the airborne transmission of AMR. After optimization of air sampling and DNA extraction protocol, the air samples will be collected at nine locations in the Belgrade metropolitan area selected according to air pollution level during four seasons. The state-of-the-art shotgun metagenomic sequencing and bioinformatic analysis of obtained sequences will provide information about microbial community composition of airborne metagenomes. In addition, sequenced airborne metagenomes will be analyzed for the abundance and diversity of resistomes (antibiotic and biocide/metal resistance genes) and mobilomes using several databases and tools. Correlation analyses will offer us insight into the effect of air pollution and seasonal variations on abundance and diversity of airborne pathogens, resistome and mobilome in the Belgrade metropolitan area. In-depth approach of the AirPollRes project will provide the first insights into intersection of AMR and air pollution in the Belgrade metropolitan area, which is highly vulnerable to these health threats. As the AirPollRes is a pioneering project in this field, the expected short-term impact is the introduction of routine monitoring of pathogenic microbes and resistance determinants in the air in Belgrade, while the longer-term impact will be reflected in the improvement of human and animal health, allowing for a longer life with higher quality.
PRJEB97947.center_name: Institute of Molecular Genetics and Genetic Engineering

PRJNA1291772.description: Environmental surveillance of HNV in wastewater influent across Ontario

PRJNA1320681.title: GERA_Environmental_Microbiome Raw sequence reads
PRJNA1320681.description: This study investigated the impact of human activity on antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in the Galapagos marine ecosystem. We focused on San Cristobal Island, which has experienced rapid urbanization and tourism pressure, and found significant wastewater contamination in the marine environment. Long-read metagenomic sequencing revealed a stark shift in genera and a higher count of antibiotic resistance genes at wastewater-associated sites. Long-read sequencing and de novo assembly of bacterial genomes and plasmids from multidrug-resistant Escherichia coli revealed frequent and rapid reassortment of antimicrobial resistance genes on plasmids to generate unique resistance profiles. These data highlight potential threats to human and animal health.

PRJNA989177.title: CDC's Traveler-Based Genomic Surveillance Program
PRJNA989177.description: Genomic surveillance and sequencing of SARS-CoV-2 variants and other pathogens from U.S. arriving international air travelers (pooled and individual) from several major U.S. airports. Sequencing conducted by Concentric by Ginkgo Bioworks as part of CDC's Traveler-based Genomic Surveillance program.

PRJNA1332394.title: High-throughput sequencing of microoganisms in Zhengzhou City Batch 2
PRJNA1332394.description: High-throughput sequencing of microoganisms in Zhengzhou City Batch 2

PRJEB90666.title: Optimizing storage, high-molecular weight DNA extraction and genome reconstructions from human faecal samples
PRJEB90666.description: We assessed the effectiveness of extracting high molecular weight DNA from faecal samples, using different combinations of collection, storage and extraction kits. Faecal samples were either immediately processed, frozen at -80°C or stored in DNA/RNA Shield, GutAlive or OMNIgeneGUT and then subjected to 3 different DNA isolation kits, totalling 32 evaluated combinations. Isolated DNA was assessed for its quality and quantity using Qubit, NanoDrop and Tapestation; taxonomic consistency of extracted microbiomes was validated using  metataxonomics.

PRJNA1328970.title: anaerobic sludge Metagenome
PRJNA1328970.description: This project investigates microbial community dynamics and the generation and dissemination of resistance genes in anaerobic sludge treating pretreated, resource-recovered, and non-pretreated pharmaceutical wastewater. Anaerobic reactors were operated with different wastewater types (including pretreatment-resource recovery and non-pretreated groups), each with biological triplicates. After a defined incubation period, sludge samples were collected, centrifuged, frozen, lyophilized, and stored for downstream omics analysis.

PRJNA1254264.title: Drain sink biofilms from academic buildings
PRJNA1254264.description: Characterization of the microbial communities of restroom sink drains in two university buildings with different age of service, with varying human occupancy, across three seasons

PRJNA1328788.title: Metagenomic assessment of bacteria collected from the International Space Station
PRJNA1328788.description: Here, we explore how stable the viable ISS microbiome is at ecological and functional levels, by using PMA treatment to track viable microbial taxonomic, functional turnover, and volatility, and quantify AMR and virulence genes at spatiotemporal scales.

PRJNA1328205.title: wastewater metagenome Raw sequence reads
PRJNA1328205.description: Wastewater samples collected from river sites in Belo Horizonte, Brazil, representing complex urban environments with diverse microbial communities and genetic material from human, animal, and environmental sources.

PRJEB96272.title: Real-time genomic pathogen, resistance, and host detection in wetland ecosystems from passive water sampling
PRJEB96272.description: Wetlands are critical ecosystems where anthropogenic pressures can create public health risks. Adopting a One Health framework, we developed and deployed an integrated surveillance strategy across twelve European wetlands with varying human impact. Our approach combines non-invasive passive water sampling with a multi-omic nanopore sequencing workflow to concurrently profile vertebrate communities (12S eDNA), the water microbiome, and antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes. The framework successfully identified sites under heavy anthropogenic influence, particularly animal farming, as locations with high relative abundances of potential pathogens and AMR genes. We established a strong source-pathogen association at a French duck farm, where a dominant eDNA signal from farmed ducks (Anas platyrhynchos) coincided with high relative abundances of the pathogen Aeromonas veronii. Crucially, leveraging long-read data for metagenomic assembly allowed us to confirm this association with high confidence by locating multiple β-lactamase genes directly on assembled A. veronii contigs. In addition to these contemporary threats, our approach also uncovered a legacy of historical pollution, identifying arsenic resistance genes (arsB, arsC) on contigs from Acidiphilium multivorum, a bacterium indicative of metal-contaminated sites. By genetically linking specific AMR determinants to potential pathogens and their likely agricultural sources, this work demonstrates a powerful framework for prioritizing sites for targeted environmental monitoring. This integrated approach moves beyond simple hazard detection to provide valuable genomic context essential for hazard identification and mitigation strategies under a One Health paradigm.

PRJNA1307202.title: Metagenomic of University Campus and Surrounding Environment Metagenome
PRJNA1307202.description: This is the raw data for metagenomic sequencing of university campuses and surrounding environments, collected from the common contact surfaces of people in areas with high pedestrian traffic

PRJNA1295580.title: Multi-drug resistance Enterobacteriaceae from wastewater
PRJNA1295580.description: This project focuses on characterizing multidrug-resistant Enterobacteriaceae isolated from influent wastewater samples collected at the Laramie Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP). Using a culture-dependent approach, influent samples were processed through serial dilutions and selective plating on antibiotic-containing media to isolate resistant strains. Species identification was performed using MALDI-TOF MS, and antimicrobial susceptibility testing was conducted via broth microdilution following CLSI guidelines. Selected isolates underwent whole genome sequencing (WGS), with data processed using bioinformatics tools such as Trimmomatic, SPAdes, Prokka, and Abricate. Resistance genes were identified using the ResFinder and CARD databases, while plasmid types, sequence types, and virulence factors were also determined. This genomic dataset provides insights into the resistome and genetic features of multidrug-resistant Enterobacteriaceae circulating in untreated municipal wastewater, contributing to wastewater-based AMR surveillance efforts.

PRJNA1314309.title: Fragmented Microplastics Synergize with Biological Treatment to Potentiate Antimicrobial Resistance Dissemination in Sewage Treatment Processes
PRJNA1314309.description: Fragmented Microplastics Synergize with Biological Treatment to Potentiate Antimicrobial Resistance Dissemination in Sewage Treatment Processes

PRJNA1313914.description: Metagenomics and Metatranscriptomics for Wastewater Treatment

PRJEB93969.title: Airborne ARGs in Nordic Urban Homes
PRJEB93969.description: Antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) in airborne dust represent an emerging concern for public health, particularly in indoor environments where external environmental pressures may shape their abundance and diversity. This study assessed the temporal and spatial patterns of airborne ARGs in indoor dust across four Nordic cities (Aarhus, Bergen, Reykjavik, and Uppsala) using electrostatic dust collectors (EDCs) at two time points: 2012 and 2022. Shotgun metagenomic sequencing was performed to profile ARGs, while national antibiotic consumption data were obtained from the European Surveillance of Antimicrobial Consumption (ESAC-Net). Outdoor air pollution data (PM2.5 and PM10) were retrieved from the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS) and meteorological parameters were obtained from the NASA POWER database. Beta diversity analysis revealed significant city-specific differences in ARG composition (PERMANOVA, R² = 0.18, p = 0.03), but no consistent temporal shift over the 10-year period. Macrolide, Tetracycline, and Aminoglycoside resistance genes were among the most abundant and persistent classes. Notably, a new resistance gene (Macrolide_85) emerged across all cities in 2022. While overall antibiotic consumption declined, its correlation with ARG abundance increased over time (Spearman’s R = 0.37 in 2022 vs. 0.25 in 2012), suggesting the persistence of ARGs despite reduced selective pressure. Several ARG classes were significantly associated with outdoor particulate matter concentrations, and these associations were further modulated by meteorological conditions. For instance, absolute humidity reduced the PM–Polymyxin resistance association, while wind speed enhanced the association between PM and sulfonamide resistance. These findings highlight the complex and context-specific interplay between antibiotic use, air pollution, meteorological parameters, and ARG dynamics in indoor air. Integrating environmental surveillance with antimicrobial resistance monitoring is crucial for assessing ARG transmission risks in built environments, particularly in the context of climate change.
PRJEB93969.center_name: Department of clinical science University of Bergen

PRJEB85528.title: Application of antibiotics for the selective isolation of previously uncultured bacteria from activated sludge
PRJEB85528.description: Wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) are essential in urban areas, ensuring the protection of both human health and the environment. Among the various technologies used for wastewater treatment, activated sludge (AS) is by far the most widespread. AS contains a complex microbial community responsible for degrading organic materials, facilitating resource recovery, and returning treated water to the environment. Understanding the composition of these microbial communities is crucial for optimizing WWTP processes. While DNA-based studies have identified which bacterial taxa are commonly found in the activated sludge and provided clues into their specific roles, culture-based methods are necessary to validate these observations. However, isolating environmental bacteria remains challenging due to the difficulty in replicating their specific growth conditions in the laboratory and competition from fast-growing bacteria. In this project, dispersed bacteria from AS were cultured in media containing ultrafiltered, sterilized AS fluid, supplemented with one of eleven antibiotics to modify microbial structure.The results showed that this method reduced microbial diversity and altered microbial composition in an antibiotic-specific manner. Although this method did not facilitate the isolation of previously uncultured genera, we successfully isolated 26 species of which 8 were novel. Five of these represent taxa previously found in AS, demonstrating that the isolation strategy can be used to obtain ecosystem-relevant species. Further attempts could be focused on tailoring growth conditions for targeting bacteria of interest after modifying the microbial profile.

PRJEB96078.title: ApoE_FXR_IHC_Air_HFD
PRJEB96078.description: Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) is characterized by intermittent hypoxia and hypercapnia (IHC) and an independent risk factor for atherosclerosis. To study the role of bile acid receptor FXR in IHC-induced atherosclerosis, we exposed ApoE-/- x FXR-/- and ApoE-/- mice to IHC or Air for 10 weeks, fed with high fat diet (HFD). Atherosclerotic lesion data revealed that IHC-induced atherosclerosis in ApoE-/- mice was not observed in ApoE-/- FXR-/- mice, suggesting that FXR plays an important role in IHC-induced atherosclerosis. Examination of microbiome and metabolome profiles in these mice will help us better understand the underlying mechanisms.
PRJEB96078.center_name: University of California San Diego Microbiome Initiative

PRJEB87859.title: Sewage surveillance of antibiotic resistance
PRJEB87859.description: Sewage contains shed bacteria from a large number of individuals. Thus, analyses of sewage could serve as a surveillance system for antibiotic resistance. With the aim to evaluate the value of sewage analyses for the surveillance of antibiotic resistance, we have compared sewage data to available clinical antibiotic resistance data in ten European countries.

PRJNA1280118.title: CDC Healthcare Wastewater Metagenomics
PRJNA1280118.description: CDC’s Division of Healthcare Quality Promotion-hosted Umbrella for any sequence data (genome, plasmid, amplicon, shotgun) generated by CDC and participating partners that are conducting facility-level healthcare wastewater surveillance. The data can include any data format, including raw reads and/or assemblies. We have implemented a standard scheme for isolate/sample identification. We request for those interested in submitting data to this umbrella project, please contact: healthcarewwater@cdc.gov to be assigned your unique code. DHQP has guidance available for posting metadata, which can be provided upon request. In general, submitters should not post any metadata that compromises confidentiality. Questions? Please email healthcarewwater@cdc.gov.

PRJEB83236.title: SEPSIS Human Microbiome Study
PRJEB83236.description: Human-associated microbes are a key determinant of human health, development and disease. For instance, microbial communities in the human gut play a vital role in host metabolism and in the stimulation and development of the host innate immune system. Perturbations to these microbial assemblies, referred to as dysbiosis, are linked to negative health outcomes including allergies, obesity, undernutrition and early childhood sepsis. Most of what we know about the microbiome comes from high-income settings. This is because, low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) are currently underrepresented in global microbiome study. In addition, recent work highlights the influence of geography on the composition and stability of the gut microbiota. For example, Prevotella, prevalent in LMICs, is virtually absent in high-income countries. Even within LMICs, the relative abundance of Prevotella varies substantially. For instance, among Bangladeshi children the presence of Prevotella is far below that in children from Mali, Kenya and The Gambia. This study will describe the composition, diversity, stability, and metabolic activity of gut and body microorganisms in Bangladeshi mother-infant pairs and examine how each of these characteristics vary temporally and by body habitat, mode of delivery, exposure to antibiotics and maternal, infant and household characteristics. In addition, it will examine the human milk oligosaccharide (HMO) profile of breast milk collected from lactating women in Bangladesh and examine how HMO profile varies temporally, and by secretor status, maternal age, parity, diet, mode of delivery, season of milk collection, infant feeding pattern, and other maternal, infant and household characteristics. This will help us understand the relationship between mother and infant gut and body microbial communities over time and in the early postnatal period, gut microbiomes and microbial derived metabolites in mother-infant pairs and finally, HMO profiles and the composition of the infant gut microbiome.
PRJEB83236.center_name: University of California San Diego Microbiome Initiative

PRJNA1304614.title: Microorganisms in the environment of broiler houses at different ages
PRJNA1304614.description: The aim of this study is to investigate the differences in microbial content (PM2.5 and TSP) in the environmental particulate matter of broiler houses at different ages and the functions of these microorganisms. To provide a theoretical basis for improving the environmental health of broilers.

PRJNA1299756.title: Analysis of microbial diversity in the environment of bactrian camel stables
PRJNA1299756.description: Analysis of microbial diversity in the environment of bactrian camel stables

PRJNA1304687.title: Metagenomic analysis of microbial communities in a three-dimensional electrode biofilm reactor for wastewater treatment
PRJNA1304687.description: A three-dimensional electrode biofilm reactor (3D-BER) was constructed using carbon felt and carbon rods as electrodes, inoculated with activated sludge, and applied for nitrate removal from wastewater. The microbial community composition and functional potential were analyzed via metagenomic sequencing to elucidate the key microorganisms and metabolic pathways involved in denitrification.

PRJNA1302164.title: Untreated Wastewater as a Reservoir of Priority Pathogens and Antimicrobial Resistance Genes in Central India
PRJNA1302164.description: DNA Metagenomics of wastewater samples in India

PRJNA1304270.title: Oxford Nanopore whole-genome shotgun reads of Rhodopseudomonas palustris CGA009 gene-deletion mutants_CGA009delta-cbbP and CGA009delta-cbbPdelta-oorABC
PRJNA1304270.description: This BioProject provides raw whole-genome shotgun (WGS) Oxford Nanopore reads for Rhodopseudomonas palustris CGA009 gene-deletion mutants: CGA009delta-cbbP, CGA009delta-cbbPdelta-oorABC. The MinION sequencing was performed on MinION Mk1C(Oxford Nanopore Technologies) with Spot-ON Flow Cell, R9 Version (FLO-MIN106D).

PRJEB88784.title: Non-antibiotic drugs enhance AMR in mixture with ciprofloxacin
PRJEB88784.description: Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a major health concern, and a range of antibiotic concentrations and non-antibiotic agents can select for AMR. Selection for AMR is often investigated using single compounds, however, in the natural environment and the human body, pharmaceuticals will be present as mixtures, including both non-antibiotic drugs (NADs), and antibiotics. Here, we assessed the effects of one of three NADs in combination with ciprofloxacin, a commonly used antibiotic that is often found at concentrations in global freshwaters sufficiently high to select for AMR. We used a combination of growth assays and qPCR to determine selective concentrations of mixtures and used metagenome sequencing to identify changes to the resistome and community composition. The selective concentration of ciprofloxacin was reduced in mixtures, and some changes in selection for specific genes or species were observed. Results show that NADs and ciprofloxacin are more selective than ciprofloxacin alone and these mixtures can cause distinct changes to the community composition. This indicates that future work should on the maintenance and spread of AMR should consider combinations of antibiotics and NADs.
PRJEB88784.center_name: European Centre for Environment and Human Health - April Hayes

PRJNA1302381.title: Viral and Prokaryotic Communities under Stresses Raw sequence reads
PRJNA1302381.description: This study aims to explore the adaptive strategies of microbial and viral communities in real environmental samples under different environmental stressors. Representative environmental samples were selected and analyzed under various stress gradients. By extracting DNA and RNA from the samples, metagenomic and metatranscriptomic sequencing technologies were employed to comprehensively understand the genomic and transcriptomic dynamics of microbes and viruses under stress. The study also focuses on the interactions between microbial and viral communities, investigating how viruses influence host gene expression and participate in the adaptation of microbial communities under stress.

PRJNA1299334.title: Aerosol sequencing automation
PRJNA1299334.description: This study seeks to automate air metagenome collection, sequencing, and analysis for genomic surveillance. The aim is to provide agnostic, automated, metagenomic aerosol sequencing of confined livestock operations to detect human and zoonotic pathogens.
PRJNA1299334.center_name: Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Lab

PRJNA1302027.title: waste water metagenome
PRJNA1302027.description: metagenome of wastewater under different algae treatment conditions

PRJEB84944.title: Shotgun sequencing of 56 mother-infant dyads from the ALADDIN birth cohort
PRJEB84944.description: ALADDIN is a prospective birth cohort study that focuses on the impact of lifestyle and environmental factors during pregnancy and childhood on the development of allergic disease. To study the role of gut microbiota in the developement of allergic disease, faecal samples from 56 mother-infant dyads were shot-gun sequenced.

PRJNA1301266.title: Long-term effects and mechanisms of sulfur-modified nanoscale zero-valent iron in enhancing anaerobic treatment of highly toxic wastewater containing 2,4-dichlorophenol
PRJNA1301266.description: The study investigated the long-term effects of sulfur-modified nanoscale zero-valent iron (S-nZVI) on the anaerobic treatment of wastewater containing 2,4-dichlorophenol. The results demonstrated that S-nZVI enriched functional bacteria associated with pollutant degradation and anaerobic digestion, while increasing the relative abundance of genes related to key structural proteins (cytochrome c and conductive pili) for microbial extracellular electron transfer.

PRJNA1085517.title: Metagenomic and metatranscriptomic sequences of biomass samples from a polit-scale SAF-MBR
PRJNA1085517.description: Metagenomic and metatranscriptomic sequences of biomass samples from SAF-MBR. The biomass was extracted from granular activated carbon.

PRJNA1297305.title: One-stage hollow-fiber membrane bioreactor for wastewater treatment and resource recovery through hydrogen-driven mixotrophic nitrogen assimilation
PRJNA1297305.description: In this study, a one-stage, H2-fed hollow-fiber membrane bioreactor (HFMBR) was developed and investigated for the treatment of synthetic wastewater and the simultaneous upcycling of waste reactive nitrogen into microbial protein through a mixed hydrogen oxidizing bacteria (HOB) culture. The effect of different hydraulic retention times, H2:O2 and CODH2:CODacetate ratios were investigated to obtain the best results in terms of ammonium nitrogen removal and assimilation, soluble chemical oxygen demand (sCOD) removal, CO2 release, biomass concentration, and protein content. The use of membrane technology leverages the bubble-less diffusion of gaseous substrates in the liquid medium, improving gas delivery to microbial cultures by enabling a direct biological uptake and avoiding gas loss and accumulation through bubbles. The microbial community composition and evolution under mixotrophic and heterotrophic conditions was also monitored and evaluated.

PRJNA1296762.title: The Price of Survival Yaks Adaptation to High Altitudes
PRJNA1296762.description: Reveal the role of yak microbiota in the high-altitude adaptation of yaks and their adaptive mechanisms

PRJNA1293144.title: Anaerobic co-digestion of carcass waste with cow manure and pig manure
PRJNA1293144.description: This experiment included the anaerobic co-digestion of carcass waste with cow manure and pig manure. The samples were collected at steady state from all reactors for whole genome shotgun sequencing. The co-digestion of reactors showed prevalence of variety of enzymes and pathways associated with anaerobic digestion than mono-digestion reactors.

PRJNA1053915.title: Oscillospiraceae bacterium MB08-C2-2 Genome sequencing
PRJNA1053915.description: Exploring the strictly anaerobic microbial diversity of the feces of black soldier fly larve

PRJNA1232646.title: Detection and characterization of viruses in metagenomic samples from outdoor microalgae ponds of Scenedesmus obliquus UTEX 393, Tetraselmis striata and Picochlorum celeri.
PRJNA1232646.description: February 2024, pond water samples collected from four open-air microalgae ponds in Mesa, Arizona, USA: one cultivating Scenedesmus obliquus UTEX 393 and one growing Tetraselmis striata and two growing Picochlorum celeri.

PRJNA1286932.title: Engineered iron-sulfur carriers for efficient mixotrophic and sulfur autotrophic denitrification in low carbon to nitrogen ratio municipal wastewater: mechanisms of biofilm enhancement and electron transfer promotion
PRJNA1286932.description: To overcome these, we developed iron-sulfur-modified carriers (FeS@MC) and integrated them into an in-situ sequencing batch reactor (S-Fe-SBR), which successfully achieved rapid startup (16 days) of SAD under low C/N conditions.

PRJNA1285669.title: Cooperative mechanism of ultrafast nitrogen removal between partial denitrification and anammox on metagenomics and metabolomics
PRJNA1285669.description: This study innovatively demonstrates the feasibility of coupling PD with anammox (PD/A) using nitrifying sludge from wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) as the sole inoculum, achieving simultaneous anammox bacteria enrichment and ultra-high-rate nitrogen removal. Rapid establishment of stable PD within 40 days, achieving an 84.6 % nitrate-to-nitrite transformation ratio (NTR). Anammox bacteria enrichment without external anammox inoculum, culminating in a nitrogen removal rate (NRR) of 1.11 kg N/(m3 d) and 95.0 % total nitrogen removal efficiency (NRE) after 190 days, the nitrogen removal performance surpassing most conventional systems. Metabolomic profiling revealed significant upregulation in three core metabolic networks: Enhanced heme synthesis can promote cytochrome c production for electron transport chain optimization in anammox reactions. Upregulation of aspartate metabolism facilitated carbon skeleton supply for anammox bacteria (AnAOB) growth and energy supply, upregulation of nucleotide metabolism boosted transcriptional activity of AnAOB and denitrifying bacteria (DNB). These mechanistic insights elucidate the metabolic synergy driving PD/A systems, advancing their scalability for energy-efficient mainstream wastewater treatment applications.

PRJEB77081.title: Role of Bile Salt Hydrolase (BSH) Overexpression in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) - LET COHORT 3
PRJEB77081.description: OBJECTIVE: This study investigates the mechanistic role of gut microbial bile acid modifications on the metabolic and reproductive features of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS). MATERIALS AND METHODS: We compared two PCOS-like mouse models using (1) 5 week daily oral gavage of letrozole (LET), and (2) 90 day subcutaneous release of dihydrotestosterone (DHT). We introduced a stably colonized engineered native bacteria (ENB) that overexpresses bile salt hydrolase (BSH) using a single oral gavage, thus facilitating bile acid deconjugation in the gut and changing the luminal bile acid pool, verified by targeted metabolomics. We analyzed the estrous cycle through vaginal cytology, and collected serum and reproductive tissues to measure hormone levels and evaluate ovarian histology. We assessed metabolic phenotype through an insulin tolerance test, EchoMRI body compositional analysis, and fasted and fed levels of insulin, glucose, and incretins. Stool was collected for 16S and untargeted metabolomics, and liver for RNA-seq. RESULTS: Both DHT and LET mouse models mimic the metabolic and reproductive features of PCOS, including insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, anovulation, cystic follicles, and hyperandrogenism. Increased adiposity was observed in the DHT model but not in the LET model, presenting both lean and obese models of PCOS. Introduction of BSH-expressing ENB restored insulin sensitivity and blood glucose levels in the LET mice without significant change in adiposity. BSH-treated LET mice also had decreased ovary weights and a decrease in serum luteinizing hormone (LH) levels with no change in follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels. Stool metabolomics and 16S analyses are ongoing to characterize differences between conditions in each model at the level of the gut. CONCLUSIONS: Taken together, these results suggest that microbiome modulation of bile acids plays a key role in the pathogenesis of PCOS. Comparison of lean and obese models of PCOS provide clues about the role of adiposity in altered insulin signaling and other manifestations of the syndrome. Additionally, differential modulation of LH and FSH implicate non-hypothalamic modulation by bile acid signaling, perhaps at the site of the ovaries or liver. IMPACT STATEMENT: Despite affecting 10-15% of reproductive age women, PCOS is not well understood and often ineffectively treated. Common interventions like weight loss can be unattainable, or an infeasible solution, particularly for those with insulin resistance independent of obesity. This study illustrates the potential of the gut microbiome as a diagnostic tool and/or therapeutic target for PCOS, and reveals novel crosstalk between the microbiome, gut, and HPG axis.
